TITLE: Pessimism about the economy is growing, a U.S. poll shows.
SUMMARY: Roughly half of those surveyed say they are worse off financially than a year ago, and most disapprove of President Biden’s handling of inflation.

TITLE: As Dockworkers Near Contract’s End, Many Others Have a Stake
SUMMARY: West Coast longshoremen and port operators say they’re determined to reach an agreement, but truckers and retailers relying on cargo are uneasy.

TITLE: Consumer Spending Weaker Than Reported, a Bad Sign for the Economy
SUMMARY: Revised first-quarter figures show spending rose only 0.5 percent, a slowdown from the 0.6 percent growth recorded in the final quarter of 2021.

TITLE: Income and Spending Rose Less Than Prices in May
SUMMARY: After the latest monthly consumer data, some analysts expect a second straight quarter of decline in the U.S. gross domestic product.

TITLE: Gas Prices Force Many to Rethink Driving, and Spending
SUMMARY: As summer trips beckon, some are traveling less, at least by car. And those candy bars at the convenience store may find fewer takers.

TITLE: Gas Prices Around the World Threaten Livelihoods and Stability
SUMMARY: Around the world, from South Asia and Africa to Europe and Latin America, the cost of filling a car’s tank, getting to work and cooking dinner has spiked.

TITLE: When Where You Work Determines if You Can Get an Abortion
SUMMARY: After the Dobbs v. Jackson decision, many women are discovering that their employer can shape major decisions in their lives even more than it did a week ago.

TITLE: Mark Zuckerberg Prepares Meta Employees for a Tougher 2022
SUMMARY: In an internal meeting this week, Mr. Zuckerberg said the tech giant was facing one of the “worst downturns that we’ve seen in recent history.”

TITLE: GM Quarterly Sales Fall Amid Shortage in Computer Chips and Other Parts
SUMMARY: General Motors, Toyota and Honda reported substantial declines in second-quarter sales, but not for lack of demand.

TITLE: Post-Roe, Women Discover How Their Employer Influences Abortion Access
SUMMARY: After the Dobbs v. Jackson decision, many women are discovering that their employer can shape major decisions in their lives even more than it did a week ago.

TITLE: How Wall Street Escaped the Crypto Meltdown
SUMMARY: As cryptocurrency prices plunged and funds failed, strict rules on risky assets helped Wall Street companies sidestep the worst. Retail investors weren’t as lucky.

TITLE: Veterans of Carter-Era Inflation Warn That Biden Has Few Tools to Tame Prices
SUMMARY: President Biden and Democrats face political peril as costs keep rising and midterm elections loom.

TITLE: Job Openings Eased, in a Sign of the Cooling Labor Market
SUMMARY: The number of U.S. positions available was 11.3 million in May, the second straight monthly decline.

TITLE: China Offers Women Perks for Having Babies, if They’re Married
SUMMARY: Beijing is giving incentives to stem a demographic crisis, but its control over childbirth and its suppression of women’s rights are making it difficult for some aspiring parents to start a family.

TITLE: Jobs Aplenty, but a Shortage of Care Keeps Many Women From Benefiting
SUMMARY: A lack of child care and elder care options has forced some women to limit their hours or sidelined them altogether, hurting their career prospects.

TITLE: Start-Up Funding Falls the Most It Has Since 2019
SUMMARY: The drop was another fallout of rising inflation and widespread economic uncertainty, and a retreat after years of a funding boom.

TITLE: Fed Moves Toward Another Big Rate Increase as Inflation Lingers
SUMMARY: As the Federal Reserve battles rapid inflation, officials are likely to stay on an aggressive path even as signs of economic cooling emerge.

TITLE: Strong Wage and Jobs Growth Keeps Fed on Track for Big Rate Increase
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve is trying to cool down the economy to bring inflation under control, but the job market is still going strong.

TITLE: Private-sector employment has recovered to prepandemic levels.
SUMMARY: Service businesses continue to climb back, but government payrolls are still short of February 2020 levels.

TITLE: Democrats Propose Raising Taxes on Some High Earners to Bolster Medicare
SUMMARY: The draft plan, which is expected to be unveiled in the coming days, is part of talks over how to salvage pieces of President Biden’s domestic agenda.

TITLE: Amazon Hub in Newark Is Canceled After Unions and Local Groups Object
SUMMARY: The e-commerce giant planned to build an airport cargo center, hire 1,000 workers and invest hundreds of millions of dollars over 20 years.

TITLE: Biden Seeks Price Cap on Russian Oil Amid Fears of Gas Shock
SUMMARY: Negotiating and selling the plan is a crucial task facing Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen as she travels to Asia in hopes of averting $7 a gallon gasoline

TITLE: U.S. Economy Added 372,000 Jobs in June, Defying Slowdown Fears
SUMMARY: The strong Labor Department report comes as consumers and businesses express increasing concern about a downturn.

TITLE: Relief Eludes Many Renters as Fed Raises Interest Rates
SUMMARY: As the central bank sharply increases borrowing costs, it could lock would-be home buyers into rentals and keep a hot market under pressure.

TITLE: High Inflation in June Puts Pressure on Interest Rates
SUMMARY: Prices climbed 9.1 percent from a year earlier, ramping up pressure on the Federal Reserve to continue raising interest rates.

TITLE: Voters See a Bad Economy, Even if They’re Doing OK
SUMMARY: A New York Times/Siena poll shows remarkable pessimism despite the labor market’s resilience. That could be costly for the Democrats, and the economy.

TITLE: Germany Hopes to Outrace a Russian Gas Cutoff and Bone Cold Winter
SUMMARY: Europe’s largest economy and key energy hub still depends on gas supplies now ensnared in conflict. Here’s how Germany is preparing and what is at stake.

TITLE: Stock Market Drop Accelerated as Recession Seemed More Likely
SUMMARY: Further losses may be on the way, even after a 20 percent drop in the first half of the year, as Wall Street continues to price in the Fed’s aggressive interest rate policy.

TITLE: China’s Economy Hits a Slump as Covid Policy Takes a Toll
SUMMARY: High unemployment, a housing market in crisis and sluggish consumer spending during lockdowns are putting pressure on Beijing in a year when officials are focused on projecting stability.

TITLE: Democrats Face Deepening Peril as Republicans Seize on Inflation Fears
SUMMARY: Economists warn that a blitz of midterm election campaign ads could push consumer prices even higher.

TITLE: Global Central Banks Ramp Up Inflation Fight
SUMMARY: Central banks in the U.S., Europe, Canada and parts of Asia are lifting interest rates rapidly as they try to wrestle breakneck inflation under control.

TITLE: Indian Rupee Hits Weakest Level Ever Against U.S. Dollar
SUMMARY: The Indian currency has lost about 7 percent of its value against the dollar this year, a victim of higher energy prices and economic uncertainty.

TITLE: How Joe Manchin Left a Global Tax Deal in Limbo
SUMMARY: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen’s signature achievement is in jeopardy if the United States cannot ratify the tax agreement that she brokered.

TITLE: Loans Could Burn Start-Up Workers in Downturn
SUMMARY: Tech workers took out loans based on the value of their start-up stock in recent years. That may come back to haunt them.

TITLE: Chipotle closes a Maine store, and workers say it’s because of a union drive.
SUMMARY: The shutdown was announced hours before a hearing on a possible vote to unionize the location, which employees said was understaffed.

TITLE: America’s Safety Net for Workers Hurt by Globalization Is Falling Apart
SUMMARY: A 60-year-old program that provides retraining to workers whose jobs are eliminated because of foreign competition has expired, leaving many at risk.

TITLE: Chipotle Closes Maine Store Looking to Unionize, Workers Say
SUMMARY: The shutdown was announced hours before a hearing on a possible vote to unionize the location, which employees said was understaffed.

TITLE: Biden’s New Economic Scorecard: The Price at the Pump
SUMMARY: The president has grown fond of boasting about a prolonged streak of falling gasoline prices, a move wrapped in risk and irony.

TITLE: Truckers’ Protests Over Labor Law Block Access to Oakland’s Port
SUMMARY: The truckers say they’re concerned that a law classifying many freelance workers as employees could hurt their ability to operate independently.

TITLE: Ice Cream Trucks Are the Latest Target of Inflation
SUMMARY: Inflation and its rising fuel prices have pushed some ice cream truck owners to the brink.

TITLE: After Enduring a Pandemic, Small Businesses Face New Worries
SUMMARY: It has been a tough few years for companies without the scale to cruise through disruption. Making money isn’t getting any easier.

TITLE: Is the U.S. Entering a Recession? Here’s Why It’s Hard to Say.
SUMMARY: The U.S. may register a second straight quarter of economic contraction, one benchmark of a recession. But that won’t be the last word.

TITLE: Fed Prepares Another Rate Increase as Wall Street Wonders What’s Next
SUMMARY: Central bankers around the world have been picking up the pace of rate increases. Now the big question looms: When will they slow down?

TITLE: Kraken, a U.S. Crypto Exchange, Is Suspected of Violating Sanctions
SUMMARY: The Treasury Department is investigating whether the crypto exchange allowed users in Iran to buy and sell digital tokens, said people with knowledge of the matter.

TITLE: How U.S. Inflation Expectations Are Being Shaped by Consumer Choices
SUMMARY: Economic policymakers are razor focused on inflation expectations after more than a year of rapid price increases. Consumers explain how they’re thinking about rising costs.

TITLE: How Will Interest Rate Increases Impact Inflation?
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve is raising interest rates to fight inflation. Some economists want more; some politicians want less. What’s the logic?

TITLE: F.T.C. Chair Lina Khan Upends Antitrust Standards by Suing Meta
SUMMARY: Lina Khan may set off a shift in how Washington regulates competition by filing cases in tech areas before they mature. She faces an uphill climb.

TITLE: Highlights From Today’s G.D.P. Report
SUMMARY: Inventories were a big drag on the G.D.P. number. Construction of homes and nonresidential structures declined. And federal spending fell.

TITLE: Tell us how the economy is affecting you.
SUMMARY: Sharing your experience will help inform our coverage of inflation, jobs, interest rates and more.

TITLE: U.S. Economy Shows Another Decline, Fanning Recession Fears
SUMMARY: Gross domestic product, in an initial reading, fell 0.2 percent in the second quarter. President Biden said any troubles would be transitory.

TITLE: Climate Change Is Probably a Drag on Growth, but It’s Unclear How Much
SUMMARY: Plenty of long-term models show that rising temperatures are bad for the economy. Estimating the impact in real time is very tricky.

TITLE: They Flocked to China for Boom Times. Now They’re Thinking Twice.
SUMMARY: Global businesses and industries that rode the China growth wave for years are bracing for the fallout of a slowing economy.

TITLE: Federal Reserve Makes Another Supersized Rate Increase to Tame Inflation
SUMMARY: The central bank raised rates by three-quarters of a percentage point and suggested additional large increases could be warranted.

TITLE: Fed’s Kashkari says officials are ‘a long way’ from backing off inflation fight.
SUMMARY: Neel Kashkari, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, said the Fed had more work to do in trying to control price increases.

TITLE: Pay growth and prices picked up, keeping the Fed on track for rate increases.
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve’s preferred inflation gauge climbed rapidly in June. Wage and benefit gains are fast, too, separate data showed.

TITLE: Are We in A Recession? Here’s Why It’s Hard to Say
SUMMARY: The U.S. may register a second straight quarter of economic contraction, one benchmark of a recession. But that won’t be the last word.

TITLE: As Inventory Piles Up, Liquidation Warehouses Are Busy
SUMMARY: Consumers are buying fewer discretionary goods and returning more. To clear their shelves, retailers are selling to liquidators at steep discounts.
